title: Lecture 11 Thread
content: <document version="2.0"><file url="https://static.us.edusercontent.com/files/7A0TMPr1qJOcgKwRz4NjxsNa" filename="Lecture 11.pdf"/><paragraph>This is for clarifying questions on Lecture 11 --- which finished up the conv-net material.</paragraph><paragraph>There was a very good question in office hours the answer to which has been added to the written pdf above but does not appear in the lecture video. </paragraph></document>
document:
This is for clarifying questions on Lecture 11 --- which finished up the conv-net material.

There was a very good question in office hours the answer to which has been added to the written pdf above but does not appear in the lecture video.

comments.content: <document version="2.0"><paragraph>Sharing my notes for Lecture 11 (normalization, ResNets, pooling, U-Nets). Tried to include clear intuitions and comparison tables.</paragraph><paragraph><bold>Question while reviewing lec 11:</bold> The ResNet ↔ ODE connection (f_{i+1} = f_i + g_i ≈ dx/dt = g) is really interesting. Has anyone explored architectures based on better numerical integrators? Like if Euler integration is ResNet, what would Runge-Kutta correspond to? And does this analogy actually give useful design insights, or is it mostly a nice mathematical observation?</paragraph><paragraph>Also curious about the Pre-Norm vs Post-Norm distinction, the notes mention Pre-Norm is more stable, but is there an intuitive reason why normalizing before the transformation helps more than normalizing after?</paragraph><paragraph><bold>Notes:</bold><break/></paragraph><file url="https://static.us.edusercontent.com/files/jg2LgSh5gkLXD3aGAGzlzQF6" filename="Lecture 11 Notes CNNs ResNets UNets.pdf"/></document>
comments.document:
Sharing my notes for Lecture 11 (normalization, ResNets, pooling, U-Nets). Tried to include clear intuitions and comparison tables.

Question while reviewing lec 11: The ResNet ↔ ODE connection (f_{i+1} = f_i + g_i ≈ dx/dt = g) is really interesting. Has anyone explored architectures based on better numerical integrators? Like if Euler integration is ResNet, what would Runge-Kutta correspond to? And does this analogy actually give useful design insights, or is it mostly a nice mathematical observation?

Also curious about the Pre-Norm vs Post-Norm distinction, the notes mention Pre-Norm is more stable, but is there an intuitive reason why normalizing before the transformation helps more than normalizing after?

Notes:
